seo.metaTitle: Male Lichen Sclerosus Treatment London | PRP & LED Therapy | Dr. SNA Clinic
seo.metaDescription: Long-term relief for male lichen sclerosus. Doctor-led PRP, light therapy, and tailored skincare plans in London. Private intimate health clinic.

schema.howPerformed: After thoroughly numbing the affected penile tissue with topical anesthetic cream, we draw 10ml of blood from your arm and process it in a dual-spin centrifuge to isolate platelet-rich plasma. Using ultra-fine needles, we inject this concentrated PRP directly into areas of whitening, scarring, or tightness—typically the foreskin, glans, and frenulum. Each micro-injection delivers growth factors that thicken fragile tissue and restore elasticity. Immediately following injections, you receive medical-grade LED phototherapy: red (630nm) and near-infrared (850nm) light is applied to the treatment area for 15 minutes to reduce inflammation and support healing. The entire session takes 45 minutes. We provide custom-compounded barrier creams and detailed hygiene protocols
schema.preparation: Clean the genital area gently the morning of treatment—no harsh soaps or scrubbing. Wear loose, comfortable underwear and trousers. If you're uncircumcised and experiencing tightness, gently retract foreskin as far as comfortable before arriving (we'll assess fully in clinic). Stop anti-inflammatory medications (ibuprofen, aspirin) 3 days before if medically safe. Bring any previous biopsy results, dermatology letters, or photos documenting progression. Optional chaperone available. Come ready to discuss intimate symptoms openly—this is a clinical, confidential environment. Shave or trim if desired but not required
schema.followup: Apply prescribed barrier cream twice daily, especially after urination—this prevents micro-tears and seals moisture. Avoid tight underwear and synthetic fabrics for one week. Treated areas may feel warm or slightly swollen for 24-48 hours. Avoid sexual activity for 48 hours to allow tissue healing. Continue LED therapy sessions as scheduled (typically 4 sessions over 2 weeks). Use your digital flare diary to log itching, tightness, or whitening so we can adjust treatment. Attend 2-week and 6-week reviews to assess tissue color, retractability, and comfort. Most men significantly reduce steroid cream frequency after first PRP session. Maintenance LED or PRP boosters every 3-6 months keep symptoms controlled and may help you avoid circumcision
schema.outcome: Within days, itching and burning sensations calm dramatically as inflammation reduces. Over 4-8 weeks, whitened areas regain healthier pink tone. Skin becomes more elastic—foreskin retracts more easily, reducing phimosis risk. Micro-tears and fissures heal, making intimacy comfortable again. Many men who were facing circumcision successfully preserve their foreskin with diligent treatment and maintenance. Dependence on potent steroid creams drops significantly—you'll use them only during rare flares. The risk of progression to severe scarring, meatal stenosis, or penile cancer reduces when inflammation is controlled. Confidence and quality of life improve. Results last 6-12 months with maintenance; treatment can be repeated as needed. This is lifelong management of a chronic condition
schema.medicationRequired: Topical numbing cream (lidocaine 5%). Optional prescribed steroid-sparing barrier creams (tacrolimus or compounded clobetasol) for home maintenance
schema.treatmentFrequency: Two PRP sessions spaced 4 weeks apart for initial treatment, plus 4 LED therapy sessions over those 8 weeks. Maintenance PRP or LED boosters every 3-6 months depending on symptom severity and flare frequency
schema.adverseOutcome: Mild warmth, redness, or swelling of treated skin for 24-48 hours. Small bruise at blood draw site. Temporary hypersensitivity for first day. Very rarely, infection at injection site (strict sterile technique used)

seriousAdverseOutcome.name: Worsening phimosis or progression requiring circumcision despite treatment
seriousAdverseOutcome.probability: Rare (less than 5%) when treatment is started early and maintenance is consistent. Some severe cases ultimately require surgery

longDescription: Lichen sclerosus can trigger itching, whitening, cracking, and tightness across the foreskin or glans. Our doctor-led programme combines anti-inflammatory platelet-rich plasma (PRP) injections, red/near-infrared LED therapy, prescription topicals, and microbiome support to rebuild healthy tissue and reduce flare frequency.\n\nWe approach LS as a chronic condition requiring discipline and empathy. Consultations happen in private suites with optional chaperones, and every plan includes digital check-ins so you can report symptoms discreetly between appointments.

faq.question: Do I still need steroids?
faq.answer: We typically taper steroid frequency but keep a rescue plan for flares. Regenerative therapy reduces reliance but doesn’t completely replace medical guidance.
LS is chronic, but our programme can keep it in remission, reduce symptoms, and protect tissue long term.
faq.question: Will this cure lichen sclerosus?
Can I stay uncircumcised?
faq.answer: Many patients maintain their foreskin with diligent care. We discuss pros/cons and coordinate with urology if surgery becomes necessary.

faq.question: Is PRP safe?
faq.answer: Yes—PRP is your own blood, processed sterilely. Side effects are limited to mild swelling or warmth for 24 hours.

faq.question: How often do I need maintenance?
faq.answer: Most men return every 3-6 months for LED or booster PRP depending on severity.

faq.question: Can LS lead to cancer?
faq.answer: Untreated LS slightly increases cancer risk. Regular monitoring and treatment reduce inflammation that contributes to cellular change.
